data.title: What's the best practice to publish a release on Github using pipelines?
data.body:
Hi.

I struggled to use Github Release Task for days but still don't know the designed workflow for this.

My code is published on Github as public, and I want to set up Azure DevOps to build and release the built packages on Github.

My tested pipilines:

1 "Create Mode": Sets Github code as artifact, builds for each platform, archives for each build, creates a new release.
Problem: Don't know what's the "target" should be set in Github Release Task. After I set it as 48b11d8d6e92a22e3e9563a3f643699c16fd6e27, it will always failed like https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/10890.
And, there is no way to let user specify the title of the release when starting releasing. I set "tag" and "release title" to "$(Release.ReleaseDescription)" as a workaround.

2 "Edit Mode": Sets Github Release as artifact, downloads the source code from the release,  builds for each platform, archives for each build, updates the release.
Problem: The attached source code is not downloaded as artifact. If using task "Download GitHub Release", don't know how to get the version / tag info from the selected artifact.

Any idea about this? What's the best practice to publish a release on Github using pipelines?

Thanks in advanced.

data.title: UseDotNet task can't install nightlies
data.body:
The UseDotNet task cannot install nightlies of .NET Core because they're not in the releases json. They are available via the blob endpoint by convention.

It required using the DotNetCoreInstaller@0 task for this to work. The v1 task also did not work.

This makes it quite hard for devs to try using the nightly SDK releases. Please add a fallback to the naming convention as in the original task.

data.title: Allow user to specify storage account for deployment packages
data.body:
When Set-AzureDeployment is run it will use whichever storage account is currently set in the subscription context under `CurrentStorageAccountName` (can be seen by running Get-AzureSubscription). If this is unset it will fail with the error `CurrentStorageAccountName is not set. Use Set-AzureSubscription subname -CurrentStorageAccountName storageaccount to set it.`.

This PR will allow the user to specify the classic storage account to use for deployment packages to resolve this error.

data.title: Update PublishSymbolsV2 to skip artifact
data.body:
Artifact association is not supported in release mode
which causes this task to never succeed in a release.
I think it's reasonable to offload symbol publishing to
release pipeline, so only attempt to associate when in
build mode.

data.title: NodeTool - Cache node binaries "locally"
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: NodeTool

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    Hosted

## Issue Description

Would it be possible to cache the node binaries "locally" (somewhere inside the azure pipelines system) so that the task isn't required to reach out to nodejs.org each time it downloads the binary? My team regularly gets tar unexpected eof errors during this task, seemingly because of the flakiness of the node CDN. There's an open issue for github actions to do something similar.
https://github.com/actions/setup-node/issues/77

data.title: Unable to use SPN variables from a Service Connection when a custom template is being used.
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
Question
**Enter Task Name**: 
PackerBuildV1

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/PackerBuildV1

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
Hosted and Private (custom)

## Issue Description

Unable to use SPN variables from a Service Connection when a custom template is being used.

It is currently not possible to use SPN variable from a Service Connection such as "client_id" "client_secret" or "tenant_id"

Currently I have to send those variables as part of the Custom Template Parameters, is there a way to get them from the Service Connection instead?

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
**Azure Pipelines**


## Issue Description
Our project is based on the **AzurePowerShellV3** task in https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks

Everything was working fine till Feb 27, 2020 and now our release is failing at Setting **AppService task**.

I am getting this error when **AppSetting task** starts to update appsettings on App service.

data.title: publishTestResults doesn't publish test results for dotnet vstest
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug-ish

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLI

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: qktech, QK Kiosk, QK Kiosk, 20200311.3

- Agent - Hosted or Private: Hosted
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: windows-latest 

## Issue Description

`publishTestResults` is [documented](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/dotnet-core-cli?view=azure-devops) as follows:

> Enabling this option will generate a test results TRX file in `$(Agent.TempDirectory)` and results will be published to the server. This option appends `--logger trx --results-directory $(Agent.TempDirectory)` to the command line arguments.

It does not do this for all commands except `test`. It will do nothing in the example below.

```
- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  inputs:
    command: 'custom'
    projects: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/drop/xxx/xxx.dll'
    custom: 'vstest'
    publishTestResults: true
```

`dotnet vstest` supports at least `--logger` [as per its documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-vstest) and the second example suggests it supports `--ResultsDirectory` (albeit not `--results-directory`).

I would appreciate if DotNetCoreCLI (i) understood `vstest` as a command but at least (ii) understand it's invoking `vstest` and set the command line flags appropriately, if `publishTestResults` is true.

### Task logs

```
##[debug]exec tool: C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe
##[debug]arguments:
##[debug]   vstest
##[debug]   D:\a\1\drop\xxx\xxx.dll
"C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe" vstest D:\a\1\drop\xxx\xxx.dll
```

data.title: Make accesible scopes for pipeline cache configurable
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: `Feature`

**Enter Task Name**: `CacheV2`

## Environment
- Server - `Azure Pipelines`:
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: `gmp-vc`, `Turbo`, `Build Turbo`


- Agent - `Hosted`: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: `Azure Pipelines\windows-2019`

## Issue Description

Could you please add one more input to the task that allows you to specify which branches it's ok to access cache entires from? Or maybe there's a better way to control this? For example, allow naming your scope key yourself (for me would be one key for all branches). Something like this has been previously suggested [here](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11374) and was implemented as `master`-only feature.

That feature landed recently and is also neat. Now builds on the `develop` branch should get read-only access to `master`-scoped caches. This allows the `develop` branch to reuse cached packages or entire built sub-apps. I also like the default behavior that makes other scopes inaccessible by default.

But, I find myself frequently needing to use this feature the other way around. It would be neat if in the `CacheV2` task we could configure which branches to allow this current task to peer into. Our relatively normal use case: we have the `Dev`, `QA` and `Prod` environments in Azure. We also have 3 main branches in git that track those precisely: `develop`, `staging` and `master`. This allows us to always know what's live, easily reproduce errors locally, etc. As soon as you push new code to `develop`, a build happens and hopefully reuses some cache entries for packages and maybe sub-apps that haven't changed at all, and then deploys the built app to the `Dev` env. To promote this to `QA` or `Prod` we simply fast-forward or merge `develop` into `staging` or `master`. But there, `staging` and `master` don't have a way to access cache entries of `develop` (although it's exactly the same source code, same commit even!). And if they don't have their own entires from previous builds - any tasks that's "new" to those branches would have to be processed for real, instead of using the cache entires already available from `develop`. This makes them run for that much longer, so sometimes we opt for manually doing the deployment through `Releases` from that single build, and then the branches don't actually show what's live. Or I'd push all branches, and then cancel 2 out of 3 builds, having also to remember to deploy to other 2 envs manually in the future. Advice on our workflow accepted, but it's mainly here to illustrate the need for added configurability.

### Task logs
`N/A`

## Troubleshooting
`N/A`

### Error logs

`N/A`

data.title: Help migrating yaml build and classic release pipelines to multi-stage yaml.
data.body:
I'm looking at migrating my old CI/ CD pipelines which are a mixture of the new YAML pipelines for builds and the 'classic' UI-based Releases pipelines into a multi-stage, environment-based YAML file, but I'm struggling to find the docs/ examples that follow along with what we are currently doing.

There are usually three environments: `Test`, `UAT` and `Production`.

They're all AKS based and at the moment the build that creates the docker container(s) will, as part of it's output, store a `DeployService.yml` file that's used by the release pipeline to update each environment (by modifying the image tag, and some environment variables) prior to running `kubectl apply -f DeployService.yml`.

Currently I've got several projects that follow this pattern:

| Name | Purpose | Type | Description |
|--|--|--|--|
| `{project-name}.ci.yml` | CI build | YAML-based | Triggered on pull-requests. Builds, run tests, etc. The only output is test results and success/ failure in Azure DevOps. |
| `{project-name}.cd.yml` | CD build | YAML-based | Builds the output upon successful PR into master. This is more often than not a docker container. |
| `{project-name} - Release` | Release Pipeline | 'Classic' UI | Release pipeline, triggered by `{project-name}.cd.yml` success and deploys into the `Test` environment. From there it's promotion to `UAT` and `Production`. |

I'd like to move them all to the newer mult-stage YAML build and release pipeline using a single file.

As it stands, I've created a new yaml file by using the new pipeline template and then copying and pasting bits of my existing CD builds.

At at the moment the new build can:

* Do a build that creates and pushes the docker container.
* Trigger the release that pushes into the `Test` environment.

As part of this, the template created a `manifests` folder in the repo that contains a `deployment.yml` and a `service.yml`. It also created an environment which connected to our `Test` AKS cluster.

So my questions are these:

1. Given the `deployment.yml` needs to contain environment specific variables (think `ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT`), how do I provide those additional environment specific variables per-release environment?
2. Can I re-create the same promotion-style release pipeline that I had using the Classic UI releases?
3. Will the CI build fit into this process at all? Or should I leave it in a separate file?
4. Given there are lots of projects that follow this pattern, and for the most part they all do the same thing but build project specific containers, is there any reusability available between repos?

data.title: Add allowPackageConflicts for npm publish
data.body:
Adding the ability to allow package conflicts on publishing to npm build. This support the scenario where npm packages gets published from a larger build, where not every build updates the npm package. In this case, if the npm package version has not been updated, the npm package doesn't need to be published and the build can just continue. 

The current behavior is that npm fails with a 403 Forbidden. "The feed already contains the package 'packageName' at version 'x.x.x'. This causes the build to be red, or when "continue on error" is set on the task, the build is yellow. We would like the build to be green, because there is no need to publish a new version. 

We try here to mimic the behavior from the nuget publish task. When the allowPackageConflicts property is set on the task, this task completes successfully when the package version has already been published.

I was not able to build or test the project locally, because of an error during the build step (https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11136), so I am hoping a build will run for this PR. If so I will update the PR based on the build results.

data.title: Nodetool fails with 7zr.exe failed with return code: 3221225781
data.body: Nodetool is failing in my job running on Windows Docker. **Nodetool**: 0.160.0 **Node.js**: v12.16.1 **Container**: `mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/sdk:3.1-nanoserver-1809` Output: ``` Downloading: https://nodejs.org/dist/v12.16.1/node-v12.16.1-win-x64.7z Extracting archive C:\__w\_tasks\NodeTool_31c75bbb-bcdf-4706-8d7c-4da6a1959bc2\0.160.0\7zr.exe x -bb1 -bd -sccUTF-8 C:\__w\_temp\4271bb50-8be1-45f3-8433-17c6da3ecddb ##[error]C:\__w\_tasks\NodeTool_31c75bbb-bcdf-4706-8d7c-4da6a1959bc2\0.160.0\7zr.exe failed with return code: 3221225781 ``` Googling around, it seems like maybe the nanoserver-1809 docker image is missing some necessary runtime libraries for `7zr.exe` ([link](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53431448/a-dockerized-c-windows-console-application-exited-with-code-3221225781)). I'm using official [.NET Docker Images](https://hub.docker.com/_/microsoft-dotnet-core-sdk/); are there other recommended images for use in Azure Pipelines? Here's the top of my yaml: ```yaml strategy: matrix: linux: vmImageName: "ubuntu-16.04" containerImage: mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/sdk:3.1-bionic windows: vmImageName: "windows-2019" containerImage: mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/sdk:3.1-nanoserver-1809 pool: vmImage: $(vmImageName) container: $[ variables['containerImage'] ] variables: node_version: 12 steps: - task: NodeTool@0 inputs: versionSpec: $(node_version) ``` ## Required Information Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction. **Question, Bug, or Feature?**: bug **Enter Task Name**: NodeToolV0 ## Environment - Server - Azure Pipelines I'm willing to share the account / project / build information privately with a Microsoft employee if that'd be helpful. _- Agent - Hosted or Private:_ **Hosted** _- If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:_ I'm not sure how to check the "queue name". Is this output sufficient?: ``` Pool: Azure Pipelines Image: windows-2019 Agent: Hosted Agent Started: Today at 10:40 PM Duration: 1m 32s ``` I'm skipping the rest of the issue template, as I strongly suspect this is more about the interaction of `NodeTool` and the `nanoserver-1809`-based Docker image. I'll gather more details if it'd help!

data.title: Download secrets echoing potentially sensitive account information
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question / Potential Bug

**Enter Task Name**: Download secrets (linked to a secrets variable group in Azure Pipelines Library)

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted (`ubuntu-latest`)
    
## Issue Description
When downloading secrets, that are from a variable group defined in Azure Pipelines Library (which is linked to an Azure Key Vault), the task echos out the Subscription Id and the name of the actual key vault itself to the logs.

Don't you think this information should NOT be echoed to the logs at all? At the very least, be "starred out" (i.e. "**")?

## Issue Description
We sometimes experience random builds to be "indeployable" - giving the error message below, EEXIST: file already exists, mkdir ...

- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    Azure Pipelines
    

    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 
https://dev.azure.com/AlbertaEnergyRegulator/47284e54-ea6f-4485-b9cd-d8c8415b3ed3/_apis/build/builds/202/logs/16

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:

    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 

## Issue Description

The URL used to identify the latest version of Func Tools is not reliable:
https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/azure-functions-core-tools/releases/latest
This could at any time return version 1 (as in this moment) or version 2 or 3.
For example from my build on Nov 11th, 2019 it got version 2.
2019-11-21T22:22:06.3422337Z Downloading: https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/azure-functions-core-tools/releases/latest
2019-11-21T22:22:06.6172728Z Latest version is 2.7.1846

Today it gets version 1.0.25 
2020-02-25T22:28:53.9696154Z Downloading: https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/azure-functions-core-tools/releases/latest
2020-02-25T22:28:54.1504760Z Latest version is 1.0.25

In this case I will not only get wrong version, but it actually fails because version 1 does not have linux artifact. See the full log bellow.

Also you can see my initial issue report and conversation on the Func Core Tools repo:
https://github.com/Azure/azure-functions-core-tools/issues/1848

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**

## Issue Description

It is not possible to use runtime variables as the input parameter for the task.
Scenario: I want to create a template that deploys into multiple environments (dev, test, prod, etc).
Instead of hardcoding those values I want to create a step in a template that sets the variable values based on environment name, and then pass those variables to the task.

I want to pass the subscription and the ConnectedServiceName as a parameter:
- task: AzureResourceManagerTemplateDeployment@3
      inputs:
        azureResourceManagerConnection: '$[ variables.azureConnection ]'
        subscriptionId: '$[ variables.subscriptionId ]'

This fails with the error:

There was a resource authorization issue: "The pipeline is not valid. Job Deploy: Step AzureResourceManagerTemplateDeployment input ConnectedServiceName references service connection $[ variables.azureConnection ] which could not be found. The service connection does not exist or has not been authorized for use. For authorization details, refer to https://aka.ms/yamlauthz."

Is there any way around this?

data.title: CopyFiles@2 task fails with ENOENT when run inside a container
data.body:
## Required Information

Related to https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11137

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
Type: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: `CopyFiles@2`

## Environment
Server - Azure Pipelines
Account name: MSRC-CCF, Project Name: CCF
Link to build: https://dev.azure.com/MSRC-CCF/CCF/_build/results?buildId=5185&view=logs&j=3832c52f-36bf-52f6-eb91-4b5c141a72e2&t=54da9b0b-fe6a-5f3d-67e2-12ae7aa76982
Private Agent on Ubuntu 18.04 running version 2.158.0

## Issue Description

Tasks fail with:

`##[error]Unhandled: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/__w/.taskkey'`

### Task logs

```
Starting: Copy logs (failure only)
==============================================================================
Task         : Copy files
Description  : Copy files from a source folder to a target folder using patterns matching file paths (not folder paths)
Version      : 2.158.0
Author       : Microsoft Corporation
Help         : https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/utility/copy-files
==============================================================================
##[error]Unhandled: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/__w/.taskkey'
Finishing: Copy logs (failure only)

```
## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

### Error logs

The problem is caused by the lack of a __w directory under the container. It is solved by mounting the agent workspace manually:

```
  - container: nosgx
      image: ccfciteam/ccf-ci-18.04-oe-0.8.0:latest
      options: --publish-all --cap-add SYS_PTRACE -v /dev/shm:/ccache -v /mnt/build:/__w/
```

Since .taskkey is already mounted by default during container initialisation, I believe the steps need to be adjusted to use that rather than rely on /__w. Alternatively, mounting /__w should happen automatically when using a container.

data.title: Removing values from debug messages

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreInstaller

dotnet core uses environment variables to control telemetry and first time experience. Please make this configurable via task parameters. It would be really nice to conveniently disable telemetry and first time experience as part of installing dotnet via this task.

data.title: Unclear how to use project's provisioning settings using Xcode@5
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question

**Enter Task Name**: Xcode

## Environment
Azure Pipelines, microsoft, definition ID 48886
Hosted Mac agents. 

## Issue Description

My team has been using Xcode@2 for a while to build and archive signed .ipa files for our iOS application. Our pipeline installs all necessary profiles and certs and then we use the Xcode task to build/archive using the project's signing settings (which match the things we install).

I have been trying to switch to Xcode@5 but have no idea which combination of settings will work. Looking at the source code for the task, I **think** I want manual signing to get plistBuddy to update the automatically generated plist with the profiles I need, but I don't want to have to specify those profiles in the task because it's redundant with the xcodeproj.

My goal is to use the provisioning profile info that is baked into the xcodeproj (so manual signing, but letting the project specify), but neither "project defaults" nor "manual" are working for me.

If I use "project defaults", the task fails to find a pbxProject (because there isn't one), falls back to automatic signing with no profiles, and the export fails:

```
##[warning]The provisioning style was not found in a pbxProject file. Automatic signing will be used. If the project uses manual signing, auto-export may fail. As a workaround, `Export options` can be set to `Plist` or `Specify`.
...
Error Domain=IDEProvisioningErrorDomain Code=9 ""<name>.app" requires a provisioning profile." UserInfo={IDEDistributionIssueSeverity=3, NSLocalizedDescription="<name>.app" requires a provisioning profile., NSLocalizedRecoverySuggestion=Add a profile to the "provisioningProfiles" dictionary in your Export Options property list.}
```

If I opt into manual signing **without specifying a profile**, because the project already does that, the build fails immediately:

```
 error: "<project>" requires a provisioning profile. Select a provisioning profile in the Signing & Capabilities editor. (in target '<project>' from project '<project>')
```

Meanwhile if we use Xcode@2 with these settings, everything works fine:

* Check _Create App Package_
* "Override Using" _Identifiers_ (the task installs all necessary certs/profiles)
* Everything else under "Signing & Provisioning" is blank/unchecked
* "Package Options" > "Export Options" is _Auto_

Can't figure out the equivalent of these settings in Xcode@5. We could probably just try manual signing and specifying the profiles in the ADO task, but if it's working in an older version it would be nice to not have to do that since we already specify these settings in the project itself.

### Task logs

Happy to share privately.

data.title: Visual Studio Test Task doesn't set env variable of current attempt when rerunning failed tests
data.body:
When running unit tests, VSTest task sets some list of environment variables like `TE.RerunFailedTests` or `DTA.RerunFailedTestCasesMaxLimit` or `TE.RerunMaxAttempts`. These environment variables are also available for test, that's useful.

When task reruns failed tests, in console output we see:
```
2020-02-12T16:01:37.6663270Z **************** Rerunning failed tests for Test run 1000048 *********************
2020-02-12T16:01:37.6663989Z Max attempts: 3; Current attempt: 1; Failed test cases threshold: 30; Failed test cases max limit: 0
```

All this information is available via environment variables, but not for `Current attempt: 1`.

It would be nice if Task/DTAHost will set environment variable. Then test would see this variable and apply additional business logic, or something else.

Screenshot of task configuration:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22616990/74428097-6ae2c300-4e69-11ea-9eea-49399d2b0866.png)

data.title: Feature Request: Inconclusive Tests Should Affect the VSTest Task State
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: VSTest

## Issue Description

When a test fails with `Assert.Inconclusive()`, the `VSTest` task still succeeds (green checkmark).  This is detrimental because users don't know that there is a problem with the test.

At the very least, the task would fail with a warning (similar to what you get when a task fails and you chose "continue on error").

Ideally, if would be configurable (i.e. allow the use to choose what happens with inconclusive tests: fail outright, fail as warning, ignore).

See also: #12302 
See also: [Visual Studio bug](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/907934/test-explorer-incorrectly-handles-inconclusive-tes.html)

data.title: XML Variable Substitution should have option to replace special characters
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug/Feature

**Enter Task Name**: IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup@0

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    - Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    - Private
      - Agent version: 2.164.7

## Issue Description

When using `xmlVariableSubstitution`: `true` on task: `IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup@0`, invalid xml characters won't be escaped. This will leave you with invalid xml if you have any variables containing characters like `&`.

Either those characters should be escaped by default, or there should at least be a configuration option to have them replaced.

`&` should be replaced by `&` etc.

The way to work around this problem at the moment is to save the variable with the value already escaped, but this does not work well if the same variable should be replaced in another file that does not need escaping (json etc).

It seems like this task did escape illegal xml characters before, but it was considered a bug and therefore removed. Ref: #4001

data.title: Bug: msbuild task not respecting UseHardenedRuntime when code signing for Mac
data.body:
Bug - Using Azure pipeline msbuild task. 

When building a Xamarin.Mac solution the build is successful but the code signing step is missing the **--option runtime**, therefor the application fails notarization by Apple with the message: "The executable does not have the hardened runtime enabled."

The Mac project (.csproj) has this set:
`<UseHardenedRuntime>true</UseHardenedRuntime>`

Expected behaviour: when running codesign the parameter **--option runtime** shall be used when UseHardenedRuntime is true.

Diagnostic output from msbuild task shows:
`2020-02-07T12:47:54.5841670Z UseHardenedRuntime = true`

But **--option runtime** is missing when codesign is executed
`2020-02-07T12:48:28.4655240Z   Tool /usr/bin/codesign execution started with arguments: -v --force --sign [our signature] "[path to our application.app]" (TaskId:312)`

**Description of issue:**

Using default settings for AzureIoTEdgeV2 "Build module images" task:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2018336/73489583-7239a500-4370-11ea-8df2-fd1bf315c725.png)

Results in the creation of expanded deployment in 'undefined' path:

This is in contrast to the behavior of the "Push module images" task, which produces output in "./config" path:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2018336/73489655-909fa080-4370-11ea-83d8-036063eb12e4.png)

**Suggested Resolution:**

Produce expanded deployment from "Build Module images" task in ./config directory similar to the behavior of the "Push module images" task

OR

Allow specific a user-defined Outputh path similar to the behavior of the "Generate Deployment manifest" task

data.title: Xcode@5 Code Signing Error when building a project with embedded framework that does not support manual signing
data.body:
## Required Information

*Type*: Bug
**Task Name**: Xcode@5  

## Environment

All

## Issue Description

`Xcode@5` fails to build an Xcode project that has multiple targets that have mixed signing needs, resulting in a Code Signing Error with this format:

```
<Framework> does not support provisioning profiles. <Framework> does not support provisioning profiles, but provisioning profile <Provisioning Profile Name> has been manually specified. Set the provisioning profile value to "Automatic" in the build settings editor.
```

In my case, I am trying to build an Xcode project produced by Unity 2019.3, which includes a new `UnityFramework` that does not support manual code signing.

According to the [Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2019.3/Documentation/Manual/StructureOfXcodeProject.html), a new set of command line arguments for `xcodebuild` are to be used to target manual code signing to the main `Unity-iPhone` target only, and leave `UnityFramework` to be able to signed automatically.

Using `PROVISIONING_PROFILE_APP` and `PROVISIONING_PROFILE_SPECIFIER_APP` instead of `PROVISIONING_PROFILE` and `PROVISIONING_PROFILE_SPECIFIER` in the `xcodebuild` command fixes this issue.

Adding a "Custom Provisioning Profile Argument Suffix" parameter to `Xcode` under the Signing action would allow this issue to be fixed. See [this blob post](https://lyricsboy.github.io/2016/11/30/xcode-8-automatic-signing-ci/) for more information about how the suffixes are used in building Xcode projects with multiple targets.

Here is a Unity produced Xcode project that can be used to demonstrate the issue:

https://content-infrastructure-uploadbucket-iuhbmg0o97e6.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/AzureXcodeCodeSignError.zip

You can attempt to build it using a command similar to this:

```
/usr/bin/xcodebuild -sdk iphoneos13.2 -configuration Release -project ./Unity-iPhone.xcodeproj -scheme Unity-iPhone archive CODE_SIGN_STYLE=Manual CODE_SIGN_IDENTITY="<Code Sign Identity>" PROVISIONING_PROFILE_APP="<Provisioning Profile UUID>" PROVISIONING_PROFILE_SPECIFIER_APP="<Provisioning Profile Name>"
```

data.title: AppCenter tasks emitting warnings
data.body:
The following tasks or packages owned by your team currently emit warnings whenever they are run "Warning: Use Cipheriv for counter mode of aes-256-ct".

[ 'AppCenterDistributeV1',
  'AppCenterDistributeV2',
  'AppCenterDistributeV3',
  'AppCenterTestV1',
]

These warnings are due to the agent upgrading the version of node it uses, which included several security patches, one of which emits this warning when it encounters an old version of the azure-pipelines-task-lib. To fix this issue, you should be able to simply upgrade your task to use the newest version of the task-lib (2.9.3).

Note that there may be some small compatibility issues between task-lib versions, especially for major versions less than 2. In particular, the match function is no longer compatible and can be replaced by minimatch.match to maintain exact compat (example of doing this here - https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/pull/12228/files).

If you have any further questions about this upgrade, feel free to reach out to @damccorm

data.title: ps1 script to add auth tasks to azdev server
File transform task: config hierarchy delimiter is fixed '.'
data.body:
I'm trying to use **File transform task in Azure Pipelines**. And I'm **providing variables from Azure App Configurations.** By using AzureAppConfiguration@2 task to fetch config values dynamically.
It works fine however I'm facing issues with hierarchical config values. In order to use App Configurations in .NET Core Apps I need to use delimiters (colon ":"). E.g. **Settings:User:Id** In this case my .NET Core App works fine.
The problem is in Azure Pipelines variables also loaded with ":". However according the documentation it must be (dot "."). So File transform task fails..
If I change my variables in App Configurations to use "." delimiters File transform works. However my .NET Core App will fail...

But I would like to use my configs in both DevOps and .NET Core as well. One very bad solution is to duplicate my Keys and Values... But it is not maintainable.

Best thing would be to add a parameter which allows us to specify a delimiter for hierarchical parameters. E.g.: "jsonDelimiter"

```
 - task: FileTransform@2
      inputs:
        folderPath: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/src/'
        xmlTransformationRules: 
        * jsonDelimiter: ":"
        jsonTargetFiles: |
          appsettings.json
```

data.title: DockerInstaller Should allow customised URL
data.body:
it's currently using "https://download.docker.com/%s/static/%s/x86_64/docker-%s%s" in https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/1eff99f26be6cbb5cb77e1a702fdbdaad5555100/Tasks/DockerInstallerV0/src/utils.ts#L71

As customer may run this in non-internet environment and need this to be downloaded from a proxy url, such as Artifactory generic remote repository, which will use exactly same path to resolve the correct version of the package.

Can we have this URL customisable is possible?


Thanks
River

data.title: PublishBuildArtifacts breaks symlinks of xCode artifacts
data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: PublishBuildArtifactsV1

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/PublishBuildArtifactsV1

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 


- Agent - Hosted or Private: Hosted
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: Hosted mac

    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 

## Issue Description

[Include task name(s), screenshots and any other relevant details]
Adding PublishBuildArtifacts to pipeline to publish artifact after it is archived causes artifact size to be bloated, since Robocopy used under the hood copies actual files and does not retain file symbolic link, thus rendering PublishBuildArtifacts task harmful for apple artifacts containing symbolic links.

### Task logs

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]
